Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story:
I walked beside my stepbrother, Sam, our backpacks bouncing in rhythm as we made our way down Maple Street. Mom always reminded me to keep an eye on him, especially since he tended to wander off or get distracted by stray cats. Today, though, my mind kept drifting to the machines at work. I was supposed to stay late and clean the filters, but I’d left early to pick up Sam. The supervisor’s text still burned in my pocket: “Those units are overheating. We can’t afford a breakdown.”

Sam tugged at my sleeve, pointing at a shortcut through the alley. “Let’s go this way! It’s faster.” I hesitated, remembering Mom’s warning about the alley and the sharp, anxious edge in my boss’s message. If I took Sam home the long way, I’d be even later to the shop. But if I let him lead us through the alley, I’d be risking his safety just to shave off a few minutes. My chest tightened as I tried to balance the weight of both responsibilities, feeling pulled in two directions, each demanding more than I could give.
